questions.question: In patients with confirmed sialolithiasis, what is the most common location of stoneformation?
Which of the following is true regarding management considerations in a patient withsubmandibular gland stones?

options.A: Surgical gland excision is the treatment of choice if patient is unresponsive to conservativemanagement
options.B: Associated chronic sialadenitis is a contraindication for sialendoscopy
options.C: Conventional radiography is mostly useless as more than 80% of submandibular stones areradiolucent
options.D: Stones proximal to the lingual nerve can be removed via an intra-oral approach

questions.explanation: If the stone is proximal to the lingual nerve, stone retrieval can be done via an intraoral surgicalapproach under general anesthesia.80% of submandibular stones are radio-opaque. Conventional radiography is useful in the initialworkup of salivary stones, but ultrasound, CT, MRI, and sialendoscopy are required for accuratediagnosis and localization (especially for smaller and parenchymal stones).The only contraindication for sialendoscopy is acute sialadenitis. This is because sialendoscopyand ductal dilation is more difficult in the setting of inflammation and there will be a greaterlikelihood of ductal trauma and potential spread of infection.Management of sialolithiasis should begin with conservative measures, oral hydration, analgesia,massaging of gland, sialogogues, and antibiotics (if there are signs of infection). If unsuccessful,the next step is based on the sialolith's size, number, and location:•Small stones (<4mm) - endoscopic removal using Dormia basket.1039•-larger stones external shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) + fragment removal or Open surgery andstone removal•Surgical excision of the gland should always be a last resortIf distal to lingual nerve: Make a longitudinal incision over the duct. Remove the stone. Suture theduct using absorbable suture.If proximal to lingual nerve: intraoral approachThe image below shows a stone in the submandibular salivary duct.

questions.question: A 56-year-old man presented with complaints of recurrent bilateral painless swelling over theparotid glands. FNAC done showed acinar cell hypertrophy without any inflammatory signs.All of the following are associated with this condition except?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and FNAC report of acinar hypertrophy are suggestive of sialadenosis.Hyperthyroidism is not associated with sialadenosis.Sialosis (sialadenosis) is defined as an asymptomatic, non-inflammatory, non-neoplasticparenchymal salivary gland disease. It is accompanied by a persistent painless bilateral swelling ofthe salivary glands, most commonly involving the parotid glands. Most cases of sialadenosis areobserved in patients between 40 to 70 years of age, and the salivary gland swellings are often softand symmetrical. On FNAC, acinar cell hypertrophy is seen without any inflammatory signs.Sialadenosis is associated with the following conditions:• Nutritional disorders•Bulimia nervosa• Vitamin deficiency• Endocrine disorders• Diabetes mellitus•Hypothyroidism1040• Metabolic disorders• Obesity• Cirrhosis• Malabsorption•••• Autoimmune disordersSjögren disease• Drug-induced• Valproic acid• Thiourea• Pregnancy• Alcoholism

questions.question: 1026A 40-year-old man on routine dental checkup was found to have the following finding onorthopantomogram. What is the reason for the finding marked with the arrow?
questions.explanation: The given orthopantomogram shows a right-sided clearly demarcated radiolucent lesionsuggestive of a stafne bone cyst. It is the most common type of ectopic salivary tissue.It presents as an asymptomatic, clearly demarcated radiolucent lesion at the angle of themandible, characteristically below the inferior dental neurovascular bundle. It is more common inmales. Usually, no treatment is required.A dentigerous cyst is a cyst in relation to an unerupted tooth. Most commonly involves the 3rdmolar. It is managed by enucleation and removal of the tooth.

questions.question: A 5 year-old-boy was brought to the OPD by his parents with a painless, soft, translucentswelling under the tongue. On examination, the swelling is as seen below. Which of thefollowing statements best describe his condition?1027

options.A: Mucous retention cyst from a minor salivary gland
options.B: Mucous extravasation cyst from sublingual gland
options.C: Mucous extravasation cyst from a minor salivary gland
options.D: Mucous retention cyst from sublingual gland

questions.explanation: The given scenario and image points to a diagnosis of an oral ranula. It is a mucous extravasationcyst arising from the sublingual gland.Ranula is a transilluminant mucocele. It is also known as "frog's belly", as it resembles the vocalsacs of a frog. It is of two types:• Oral ranula - It is a benign cystic lesion formed by extravasation of mucus, involving thesublingual gland. Clinically present as cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth. On examinationfluctuation test and transillumination test is positive. It is conservatively managedby marsupialisation. Definitive management is excision of the cyst. Some may resolvespontaneously.• Cervical or plunging ranula- is a rare type of retention cyst arising from the sublingual gland.The mucous passes through the mylohyoid muscle diaphragm to enter the neck. Clinically presentas intraoral and cervical swelling. Diagnosis is made by USG or MRI. Management includesexcision of sublingual gland + aspiration of saliva out of the sac.1041Note: Oral ranulas located in the floor of the mouth can often be confused with an epidermoidcyst.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding salivary gland tumors?

options.A: 90% of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant
options.B: The submandibular gland is the most common site for salivary tumors
options.C: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland
options.D: A salivary gland tumor with perineural invasion is mucoepidermoid carcinoma

questions.explanation: 90% of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, and the common sites are the upper lip,palate, and retromolar regions.Option B: The most common site for salivary tumors is the parotid gland, mostly involving thesuperficial lobe.Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland.Option D: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is known to be associated with perineural invasion.

questions.question: A man presents with a slowly progressive swelling over the past 1 and 1/2 years. Onexamination, it has a variable consistency and appears as shown in the image. What is theprobable cause?1028
questions.explanation: A slowly progressive swelling, with a variable consistency, lifting the ear lobe, is suggestive ofpleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland.Pleomorphic adenoma, the most common benign salivary gland tumor, primarily affects theparotid gland, particularly its superficial lobe. It is also referred to as a mixed tumor due to itscombination of epithelial and mesenchymal components. This tumor most commonly occurs infemales around the age of 40.Clinical features:• Painless, slow-growing swelling• Lobulated, firm, variable in consistency• Lifts the earlobe• No facial nerve involvement• Curtain sign positive - cannot be moved above the zygomatic bone..• In case of deep lobe involvement, tonsils, and faucial pillars will be pushed medially.• Features of malignancy - a sudden increase in size, ulceration of the overlying skin, facial nervepalsy (involvement of facial nerve), painful swelling, and restriction of jaw movements.Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is the investigation of choice in diagnosing pleomorphicadenoma. Open biopsy is contraindicated due to the chances of injury to the facial nerve.All tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficialparotidectomy. Radical parotidectomy is performed for malignant pleomorphic adenoma.Other options:Option A: Adamantinoma is a low-grade malignant tumor that usually presents with pre-tibialpain and swelling since it most commonly affects the tibial diaphysis.Option B: Dermoid cysts present as firm painless subcutaneous nodules and are of 4 types:1042•Sequestration dermoid - sequestration of epithelium during embryological development.• Tubulodermoid - accumulation of secretions from ectodermal tube/duct•Implantation dermoid - implantation of the epidermis due to trauma• Teratomatous dermoid - having all 3 germ layers (ecto, meso, and endoderm)Option D: Sebaceous cysts are retention cysts of the sebaceous glands that present as smooth,non-tender, non-transillumination swelling with a punctum (in 70% of the patients).

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presented with painless swelling in front of the left ear for the past 2years. On examination, her left earlobe was lifted and the curtain sign was positive. Which ofthe following is false about the condition?

options.A: Treatment of choice is total radical parotidectomy
options.D: Malignant form shows LMN facial palsy

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma. The treatment of choice issuperficial parotidectomy.Clinical features:•Painless, slow-growing swelling• Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard in consistency• Lift the ear lobe• Free from deeper structures• With no facial nerve involvement• Curtain sign positive - cannot be moved above the zygomatic bonePleomorphic adenoma involves the superficial lobe of parotid gland and should be managed bysuperficial parotidectomy.Types of Parotidectomy• If only the superficial lobe is involved:•Superficial parotidectomy - only superficial lobe removed. Usually done in benign conditions.• If both lobes are involved:• Total conservative parotidectomy - both lobes are removed but the facial nerve is preserved.• Total radical parotidectomy - both lobes and facial nerve removed.Sometimes it may undergo malignant transformation. The malignant form is mixed malignanttumor or carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma (most aggressive salivary malignancy).Signs of malignant transformation• A rapid increase in size•Pain and ulceration.• Facial nerve involvement (LMN)• Lymph node involvement• Restricted jaw movements1043

questions.question: Technetium-99m pertechnetate scintigraphy done for a patient with a chronic painless facialswelling is shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this tumor?1029

options.B: Superficial parotidectomy is the treatment of choice.
options.C: Histology shows a double layer of epithelial cells with dense lymphoid stroma
options.D: It is the most common unilateral benign tumor of the parotid gland

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and image are suggestive of Warthin's tumor. These tumors appear ashot spots on radionuclide scans because of the high mitochondrial content in oncocytes thatincorporate technetium-99m. The most common benign tumor of the parotid gland ispleomorphic adenoma.Warthin's tumor or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum usually presents as a unilateraltumor. It is usually seen in the lower poles of the parotid and is commonly associated withsmoking. It occurs most often in elderly males. It has no malignant potential.Histology shows tumor cells lined by a double layer of neoplastic epithelial cells resting on thedense lymphoid stroma. FNAC is the preferred investigation. Superficial parotidectomy is thetreatment of choice.Warthin's tumor HPEOMARROWNote: Both pleomorphic adenoma and Warthin's tumors commonly present as unilateral tumors.A bilateral presentation is usually rare. However in rare cases, if there is a bilateral benign salivarytumor, the tumor is most likely to be a Warthin's tumor.

questions.explanation: Godwin's tumor•Benign lymphoepithelial tumor of the salivary gland.• It is associated with CMV..• < 5% shows malignancy - known as Eskimoma.Kuttner's tumor is chronic sclerosing sialadenitis of the submandibular gland.Oncocytoma (oxyphil adenoma) -•• Usually benign, originating from oncocytes.1044• Grossly tan-colored small, well-circumscribed, and encapsulated.-• Microscopically - large oncocytes with swollen granular cytoplasm.••Appear as a hotspot on Technetium-99m pertechnetate scintigraphy due to an abundance ofmitochondria.TumorGodwin's tumDescriptionBenign lymphoepithelial tumorEskimomaorMalignant salivary gland tumorKuttner's tumChronic sclerosing sialadenitiorSoncocytomaHotspot on 99Tc scintigraphy

questions.question: An elderly woman presents with recent onset facial asymmetry and a lump over the roof ofthe mouth for the past 1 year. On examination, a solitary erythematous swelling with diffuseborders is seen over the left hard palate. Biopsy of the lesion reveals a swiss cheese pattern.Which of the following conditions is she likely to have?
questions.explanation: The given scenario and biopsy finding is suggestive of adenoid cystic carcinoma. Facialasymmetry points to the perineural invasion of the tumor into the facial nerve, which ischaracteristic of adenoid cystic carcinoma.It is the second most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland. It is a slow-growing tumormost commonly involving the parotid and submandibular glands. Histology shows a swiss cheesepattern. The tubular type has the best prognosis, while the solid type has the worst.It has a deceptively benign histologic appearance characterized by indolent, locally invasivegrowth with a high propensity for local recurrence and distant metastasis. The most common siteof distant metastasis is the lung. Treatment involves removal of the gross tumor, with radiationtherapy for the microscopic disease.

questions.explanation: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor, while pleomorphicadenoma is the most common benign tumor of the parotid gland.Histological classification and incidence of tumors of salivary glands:NOS: Not otherwise specified.Benign TumorsIncidenceMalignant tumorsIncidencePleomorphic aden50%Mucoepidermoid carcin15%omaomaWarthin's tumor5-10%Adenocarcinoma (NOS)10%1045Benign TumorsIncideMalignant tumorsIncidencenceOncocytoma1%Acinic cell carcinoma5%Other adenomas5-10%Adenoid cystic carcino5%maBasal cell adenom 1-2%Malignant mixed tumor3-5%aCanalicular adeno 1%maDuctal papillomasSquamous cell carcino1%ma-Other carcinomas2%

questions.question: As a 1st year resident assisting in a superficial parotidectomy, you have been asked to identifythe facial nerve trunk. All of the following structures can be used for its localization except:
questions.explanation: The inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle is not used as an anatomical landmark for theidentification of the facial nerve trunk.There are two methods for localization of the facial nerve trunk:1. Anterograde method: In this method, the facial nerve trunk is identified based on theanatomical landmarks after it exits from the stylomastoid foramen. The anatomical landmarksinclude:• Conley's pointer is the inferior portion of the cartilaginous canal. The facial nerve trunk lies 1 cmdeep and inferior to its tip.• Posterior belly of digastric- The facial nerve lies superior to the upper border of the muscle.•Mastoid process- Upon drilling it, the nerve is identified proximally.• Squamotympanic fissure is a fissure in the temporal bone, which runs from TMJ to the tympaniccavity. The facial nerve runs through this fissure.•Styloid process- The facial nerve lies superficial to it.2. Retrograde method: In this method, the main branches of the facial nerve trunk are identifiedand are then traced proximally until the main tunk is identified. Some of the main branches thatare commonly used for tracing the facial nerve trunk include:• Buccal branch lies in relation to the parotid gland•Marginal mandibular branch lies in relation to the facial vessels• Temporal branchThe given image points to the facial nerve (marked by arrow).1046ParotidglandFacialnerve.Posteriorbelly ofdigastric.Localisation of facial nerve inparotid surgerySternocleidomastoid muscleEar canal-cartilageConley'spointerMastoid tip

questions.question: Which nerve is involved in Frey's syndrome?
questions.explanation: The auriculotemporal nerve (V3 nerve) is involved in Frey's syndrome (gustatory sweating).Frey's syndrome is also known as Dupuy syndrome or auriculotemporal syndrome. It commonlydevelops after parotid surgery. It is caused by an aberrant regeneration of post-ganglionicparasympathetic nerve fibers crossed along the sympathetic pathways to the sweat glands near theparotid region.Clinical features are due to the result of salivary stimulation (by the smell or taste of food) leadingto the sweating and flushing of the periauricular region on the involved side of the face. A starchiodine test is used for diagnosis.Treatment ranges from antiperspirants (in mild cases) to tympanic neurectomy or botulinumtoxin injection (in severe cases). It can be prevented by incorporating careful extracapsulardissection and closure of the superficial musculoaponeurotic layer during parotidectomy.1048GreateroccipitalnerveThirdoccipitalnerveC4Innervation of the scalpLesser occipital nerveGreat auricular nerveVertexOMARROWSupratrochlear-nerve (V1)Supra-orbitalnerve (V1)-Zygomatico-temporalnerve (V2)-Auriculotemporal nerve (V3)Other options:Option A: Facial nerve is the 7th cranial nerve that supplies the muscles of the face, and results infacial paralysis if injured during parotidectomyOption B: Oculomotor is the 3rd cranial nerve which supplies the extraocular muscles. If injuredduring ophthalmic surgeries, it results in ocular paralysis and the eye pointing down and out.Option D: Glossopharyngeal nerve is the 9th cranial nerve and its injury causes loss of tastesensation from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue.

questions.question: After parotidectomy patients complains of loss of sensation while shaving. Which nerve ismost likely affected?
questions.explanation: After parotid surgery, the nerve involved in the loss of sensation while shaving is the greatauricular nerve.The great auricular nerve (GAN) originates from the second and third nerve roots of the cervicalplexus (C2-C3). It supplies the skin over the lower pinna, pre-auricular region, and angle of themandible (image below). The main trunk passes over the sternocleidomastoid and into theanterosuperior portion of the parotid glands and branches into the anterior and posterior GAN.The anterior branch of GAN is often injured during parotid surgery during the initial elevation ofthe skin flap.When GAN is injured, it can cause reduced sensations in the earlobe, pre-auricular skin, and theangle of the mandible that can interfere with habits such as shaving, wearing earrings, etc.1049Greateroccipitalnerve (C2)Third occipitalnerve(C3)Lesser occipitalnerve (C2)C4Greater auricularnerveInnervation of the scalpVertexOMARROWOpthalmicnerve (V1)SupratrochlearnerveSupraorbitalnerveZygomaticotemporalnervesMaxillary nerve (V2)AuriculotemporalnerveMandibularnerve (V3)Other options:Option A: The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3 of trigeminal)supplies the posterior part of the temple, tragus, and adjoining auricle. It does not supply the areawhere a person is likely to shave. However, the injury to the auriculotemporal nerve resulting inaberrant regeneration would result in Frey's Syndrome (gustatory sweating).Option C: Though the facial nerve is the most common nerve affected during parotidectomy, anydamage would result in facial paralysis and not loss of sensation of the face.Option D: The mandibular nerve is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) that suppliesthe skin over the mandible, lower lip, and cheek. However, they are not injured duringparotidectomy.

questions.question: A 57-year-old male patient presents to the surgery OPD, with a 7cm lesion over the left buccalmucosa and difficulty opening the mouth. On examination, the right cervical lymph node is4cm in size with overlying skin involvement. What is the TNM staging of this lesion?

questions.question: What is this approach used in the treatment of oral cancer?
questions.explanation: The given image shows the visor approach.In the visor approach, an incision is made extending from one end of the mandible to the oppositeside and subplatysmal flaps are elevated superiorly over the mandible (like a visor of a helmet).This approach provides a wide exposure to remove larger lesions involving the anterior oralcavity that is not amenable to a peroral approach. This avoids a lip-splitting incision but has thedisadvantage of anesthesia of chin/lower lip (due to the sacrifice of submental nerves).The surgical approach selected for excision of oral cavity tumors depends on the size of the tumor,location (anterior vs posterior), proximity to bone (mandible or maxilla), and the need to performneck dissection. The most commonly employed approaches are as follows:• Peroral accessible early-stage tumors-• Lower cheek flap - tumors requiring partialmandibulectomy or large posterolateral tumors that cannot be accessed via a peroral approach1053•• Upper cheek flap - tumors requiring partial maxillectomy or those involving the hard palate,upper gum, upper gingivobuccal sulcus and anterior soft palate• Mandibulotomy -larger tumors of the posterior oral cavity, tumors that involve the base of the tongueor pharyngeal wall.• Visor flap - larger lesions of the anterior oral cavity involving the anterior floor of the mouth andlower gum that are not amenable to a peroral approachCommando operation is the combined mandibular resection and neck node dissection. It is usedmainly for carcinoma of the tongue.

questions.question: To which group of lymph nodes does a tumor limited to the glottis of the larynx spreadcommonly?
